author: Saphora Smith
title: Londoner gives homeless women free makeovers to 'regain their dignity'
text:
Monday 30 January 2017 09:28 BST Click to followThe Evening Standard Roxana Mohammadian-Molina gives a lady a makeover Roxana Mohammadian-Molina 
A London businesswoman has given homeless women free makeovers to help them “boost their confidence and self-worth.” 
Roxana Mohammadian-Molina, 34, organised a "pampering day" with the Whitechapel Mission homeless charity in east London, to help the women "regain their dignity and strength to make a positive and lasting difference in their lives.” 
Ms Mohammadian-Molina, who used to run a beauty business, led a team of beauticians to transform a room at the charity’s headquarters in Tower Hamlets into a professional-style salon offering free hair, makeup and nail treatments. 
Dozens of homeless women, many of whom suffer from domestic abuse, turned up to the event which the charity hopes to make a monthly occasion. Women get their nails done at the Whitechapel Mission in east London 
Ms Mohammadian-Molinasaid said it was “priceless” to watch the women “forget about their individual issues for a few hours and just enjoy themselves” and “to see them smile and feel happy.” 
She told the Standard: “Some of the ladies I did a skin cleansing on said to me they’d never had their face cleansed before. 
“One lady couldn’t believe we were using good brands such as Yves Saint Laurent on her. She clearly recognised the brand but it says a lot about her self-worth that she almost thought the brand was too good for her.” A lady gets her makeup done at Whitechapel Mission 
Ms Mohammadian-Molina said personal experience had convinced her of the power of makeup and looking good. 
She said: “I grew up in Iran in the eighties and nineties when women could not wear a hint of makeup. 
“Then I moved to Britain and started working for an investment bank which was a very male-dominated environment. 
“I quickly realised I felt empowered and capable when I looked good. Makeup made me feel like I could get up and achieve.” A woman has her hair straightened 
She added: “I hope for these women feeling good about their appearance could be the first step towards believing in themselves and their ability to change their lives, to get back into society.” 
Tony Miller, director of Whitechapel Mission, welcomed the initiative and said he hoped it could become a regular event. 
He told the Standard: “We need to raise these women’s self-esteem to try and get them to understand their true value. Roxana Mohammadiam-Molina poses with one of the women after her makeover 
“We want to say ‘girls you’re worth more than this and we want you to understand that.’ 
“Something as daft as sitting and talking while someone does someone’s nails can make the biggest difference to somebody who has never had that experience before. It’s an intimate thing. 
“As a charity we're often asked about positive results but sometimes it’s just about acknowledging that someone is a person and has value.” More about:
